newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia external balance seen improving by 2000.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia external balance seen improving by 2000.

text.p: The current account of Malaysia's balance of payments is expected to register a surplus of about 1.3 percent of gross national product (GNP) in the year 2000, the government said on Thursday.
In its Second Industrial Master Plan 1996-2005 released on Thursday, Malaysia said the surplus in the year 2000 compared with a deficit of 8.8 percent of GNP in 1995.
However, the services deficit is expected to show only "marginal improvement" during the plan, said the report, prepared by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
Exports of goods and non-factor services are expected to grow at 9.4 percent per year during the 10-year plan period, the report said.
"This is largely due to the improved competitive position of the country and the expected prospects for world trade," the report said.

Growth of imports at 8.3 percent during the 10 years will be slower than in previous years, the report said. "This is the result of increases in domestic production of some of the intermediate and investment goods," it said.
